title-group.article-title: Is Economic Transition Harmful to China’s Urban Environment? Evidence from Industrial Air Pollution in Chinese Cities

author-notes.corresp: Canfei He and Yan Yan are in the Department of Urban and Economic Geography, College of Urban and Environmental Sciences, Peking University, 5 Yiheyuan Road, Haidian District, Beijing, 100871, China. E-mail: hecanfei@urban.pku.edu.cn and yanyanpku@163.com.
Fenghua Pan is in the School of Geography, Beijing Normal University, Beijing 100875, China. E-mail: panfenghua@gmail.com.

abstract.p: Economic transition has posed a serious challenge to environmental protection efforts in China. This study explores the environmental effects of the triple transition process of marketisation, globalisation and decentralisation using data on industrial SO2 and soot emissions at the prefecture-city level. Panel data regression results find that marketisation and decentralisation have been harmful to the urban environment while economic globalisation has been beneficial to urban air quality. As is to be expected, state-owned enterprises have contributed to China’s environmental degradation. However, the environmental impacts of the triple processes of economic transition only occur in the coastal and central cities. The results imply that the institutional perspective provides an important angle to understand the issue of environmental deterioration in China.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: China has received constant attention for both its rapidly growing economy and the serious environmental degradation that has occurred since the 1980s. The high-growth, resource-intensive and export-oriented development strategy that China has pursued, coupled with the norms and institutional relationships designed to support this development strategy, have no doubt posed a serious problem for environmental protection efforts in China (Jahiel, 1997, 1998; Chan and Yao, 2008). The growth in industrial and municipal waste, vehicle emissions, energy consumption and deforestation has cast serious doubt on the sustainability of China’s development path. As Naughton noted

disp-quote.p: the challenges of water availability, resilience of the natural environment and atmospheric degradation and climate change are among the most serious that China confronts (Naughton, 2007, p. 503).

sec.p: There are limited studies examining air pollution across Chinese provinces or industries using the framework of the environmental Kuznets curve (EKC) (Poon et al., 2006; He, 2006, 2009, 2010). The working paper series of the World Bank has explored the influence of pollution charges, environmental subsidies, the enforcement of environmental regulations, ownership and the bargaining power of factories and community pressures on the emissions behaviour of industrial polluters in China (Wang and Chen, 1999; Wang, 2000; Wang and Wheeler, 2000; Dasgupta et al., 2001; Wang et al., 2001; Wang and Jin, 2002). These studies have certainly advanced the knowledge of industrial pollution in China. However, a systematic investigation of the relationship between economic transition and industrial air pollution is lacking. China’s economic transition has been conceptualised as a triple process of marketisation, globalisation and decentralisation, with each of these processes exerting different environmental impacts.

First, marketisation allows multiple ownership in the Chinese economy. State-owned enterprises (SOEs) principally enjoy more bargaining power than non-SOEs and build strong connections with local governments and may have less incentive to reduce air pollution. Non-SOEs are profit oriented and lack strong incentives to internalise environmental costs, given the lax enforcement of environmental regulations. In this context, marketisation may be a process that has the capacity to damage China’s urban environment. Secondly, globalisation has ambiguous impacts on industrial pollution in Chinese cities since there exist complex relationships between foreign investment and international trade and industrial pollution. On the one hand, the pollution haven hypothesis proposes that international trade and foreign investment are harmful to the environment in developing countries whose environmental regulations are weaker. On the other hand, economic globalisation may encourage the diffusion of environmental friendly technological and managerial innovations and global environmental norms, helping to improve local environment quality (Shin, 2004). Thirdly, regional decentralisation results in insufficient authority and lack of co-ordination between institutional factors in China’s environmental protection apparatus (Jahiel, 1998). Regional fiscal decentralisation has the potential to trigger the ‘race to the bottom’ competition, in which cities lower their environmental standards to compete for businesses and even attract pollution-intensive industries. As a consequence, economic transition would provide a good persepective from which to understand the environmental degradation in China.

Using data on industrial SO2 and soot emissions in Chinese cities during the period 2004–08, this study first maps the city distribution of industrial air pollution intensity and identifies the hotspots of industrial air pollution. This study then performs a systematic investigation of the economic and institutional determinants of industrial air pollution intensity. The statistical results presented here identify some evidence of EKC effects in Chinese cities. Furthermore, results indicate that marketisation and decentralisation have contributed to environmental degradation, while globalisation has been beneficial to China’s urban environmental.

The paper is structured as follows. After this introduction, the next section focuses on the relationship between economic transition and industrial air pollution. The third section examines the structural and spatial patterns of industrial air pollution. The paper then investigates the economic and institutional determinants of industrial air pollution intensity using a panel data modelling technique and concludes with a summary of major findings.

sec.title: Industrial Air Pollution in China: A Perspective of Economic Transition
sec.p: Industrial air pollution is associated with economic development in a non-linear fashion. As a region develops, industrial pollution increases, but at some level of income, this upward trend reverses and industrial pollution declines as regions attain higher levels of economic development. This inverted U-shaped relationship between economic development and industrial pollution has been labelled the environmental Kuznets curve (EKC) in a sizeable literature (Grossman and Krueger, 1991; Selden and Song, 1994; Holtz-Eakin and Selden, 1994; World Bank, 1992; Cole et al., 1997; Moomaw and Unruh, 1997; Panayotou, 1997; Harbaugh et al., 2002; Cole, 2003; Poon et al., 2006; He, 2009, 2010). Often using industrial or provincial data, this literature seeks to test the existence of EKC in China. For instance, Poon et al. (2006) and He (2009) found the presence of EKC for SO2 emissions at the provincial level. It is generally agreed in the literature that economic growth has both harmful effects on environmental quality and beneficial effects. The harmful effects come via the scale effects and the beneficial effects come via shifts towards cleaner sectors and cleaner production techniques (Grossman and Krueger, 1991).

Institutions, however, can significantly shape the relationship between economic development and industrial pollution (Panayotou, 1997). Better policies such as better enforcement of contracts and effective environmental regulations can help to flatten the EKC and reduce the environmental price of economic growth. In China, pollution demand and supply are no doubt affected by institutional changes associated with economic transition, which has been conceptualised as a triple process of marketisation, globalisation and decentralisation. Marketisation, globalisation and decentralisation would exert different direct and indirect impacts on the environmental behaviour of industrial enterprises and on the local government’s attitudes towards environmental regulations.

sec.title: Marketisation and Industrial Air Pollution
sec.p: China’s economic transition is a process of change from a centrally planned economic system to a market-oriented economy. Marketisation has encouraged the remarkable development of non-SOEs, including limited liability corporations, shareholding companies, jointly owned enterprises, privately owned enterprises and foreign-owned enterprises. SOEs, however, largely remain in the heavy and capital-intensive industries, such as the energy sector, machinery and equipment manufacturing, ferrous and non-ferrous metal smelting and pressing, petroleum refining and coking, and chemical industries.

In principle, non-SOEs are able to utilise resources more efficiently and produce less air pollution with the same resources. They have relatively lower bargaining power with local authorities with respect to the enforcement of pollution charges and regulations as well (Wang and Jin, 2002). This suggests that a better environment could be achieved with a greater presence of the private sector. Using annual data for 44 developing countries from 1987 to 1995, Talukdar and Meisner (2001) found a significantly negative relationship between the degree of private-sector involvement in their economies and CO2 emission levels, suggesting that an increased role by the private sector in an economy is more likely to help the environment. However, non-SOEs are solely profit-oriented and may not seek to internalise environmental externalities and may compromise the environment to avoid the potential cost of environmental investments (Eiser et al., 1996). As China’s non-SOEs have grown rapidly, it has become increasingly difficult to enforce environmental policy as institutional channels of state control over industry become weaker (Jahiel, 1997). In the Chinese context, we therefore hypothesise that the marketisation process would be positively associated with industrial air pollution intensity.

Meanwhile, SOEs in China enjoy stronger bargaining power with local governments regarding environmental regulations in contrast to the privately owned enterprises (Wang and Jin, 2002). SOEs are often closely connected with local governments and some managers of SOEs have higher political status than the local environmental authorities. As a result, SOEs are able to elicit a lower pollution punishment and, as a result, are less likely to decrease their air pollution. Using plant-level data, Wang and Wheeler (2000) found that SOEs are more likely to pollute than private enterprises, which is further confirmed in a study by Wang and Jin (2002). We also expect that more SOEs would hurt China’s urban environment.

sec.title: Economic Globalisation and Industrial Air Pollution
sec.p: China has been increasingly integrated with the global economy through the utilisation of foreign direct investment (FDI) and international trade. The net environmental effect of economic globalisation in China is, however, debatable. The pollution haven hypothesis proposes that pollution-intensive industries would migrate to weakly environmentally regulated regions to save costs. Meanwhile, China may hold its lax environmental policies to give producers an advantage in the competitive international market, generating the so-called eco-dumping hypothesis (Christmann and Taylor, 2001). Both the pollution haven hypothesis and the eco-dumping hypothesis assume that economic globalisation would be harmful to China’s urban environment.

In opposition to this theorisation, economic globalisation is likely to help the environment through technique and structural effects. For example, globalisation can encourage technological and managerial innovations beneficial to environmental improvement. Trade and investment liberalisation also enable favourable conditions for the diffusion of global environmental norms and standards by creating opportunities and necessities for environmental institution-building and policy processes (Shin, 2004). Trade liberalisation may encourage governments to ensure the compliance of their exporting products with the environmental quality standards of importing countries or international standards. In turn, FDI may induce policy changes as a responding strategy to cope with possible environmental damages. As widely acknowledged, China is abundant in cheap labour and has attracted a large number of foreign enterprises in labour-intensive industries or in labour-intensive assembly functions and has exported their products to the international market. Comparatively, labour-intensive industries or functions generate less pollution than heavy industries. In summary, light industrial structure, advanced technology and higher environmental standards would make globalised regions less polluted.

The existing literature has generated mixed results in examining and analysing the relationship between economic globalisation and pollution emissions in China. Christmann and Taylor (2001) found that foreign ownership and exports to developed countries increase the self-regulation of environmental performance in China. Wang and Jin (2002) found that foreign-invested firms perform better environmentally than state-owned and privately owned firms because they use superior technology in production and are more energy efficient. He (2006, 2009), however, provided evidence to support the pollution haven hypothesis in China. Given the complex relationship between international investment and trade and industrial air pollution, we do not have a specific research hypothesis regarding whether economic globalisation is harmful or beneficial to China’s urban environment.

sec.title: Regional Decentralisation and Industrial Air Pollution
sec.p: The Chinese government has granted much autonomy and responsibility in environmental policy to local authorities since the 1980s (Jahiel, 1997, 1998). Environmental protection agencies now report to the Ministry of Environmental Protection and the local governments where they reside. The local governments provide environmental agencies with their annual budgetary funds, approve institutional advancements in rank and determine increases in personnel and even the allocation of such resources as cars and office buildings. Increasingly stringent budgeting has created a more difficult climate in which local environment protection agencies operate. As a consequence, China’s environmental protection apparatus has suffered from insufficient authority and lack of co-ordination between institutional actors (Jahiel, 1998). Such a fragmented governance structure and regulatory environment have undermined the enforcement of environmental policies. Environmentally institutional decentralisation would contribute to China’s environmental degradation.

Economic transition in China has also granted local governments the primary responsibility and greater autonomy for economic development in their jurisdictions. In particular, regional fiscal decentralisation has enhanced the importance of local revenues since localities had to self-finance their budgets and their own development (Zhao and Zhang, 1999). Under fiscal decentralisation, local governments often face restrictive budgets and local officials have become increasingly entrepreneurial in attempting to promote economic and revenue growth in their localities (Oi, 1995). Therefore, fiscal decentralisation may trigger a ‘race to the bottom’ competition in which regions lower environmental standards to compete for businesses. The decentralisation of economic decision-making to local governments, combined with calls for rapid economic growth, have created further incentives for local governments to pursue economic growth at the expense of environmental degradation (Jahiel, 1997). Local governments have strong incentives to circumvent those policies that might constrain local growth, such as environmental regulations (Lieberthal, 1995). Therefore, it can be postulated that destructive regulatory competition in the form of a race to the bottom would lower environmental quality with regional decentralisation. Existing studies report that local governments have consistently undermined pollution enforcement in order to protect local economic interests (Ma and Ortolano, 2000; Jahiel 1998, 1997; Swanson et al., 2001; Tang et al., 2003). Taguchi and Murofushi (2010) also found evidence on the interjurisdictional competition for polluted industries in China. With decentralisation, pollution-intensive industries gain opportunities to grow in cities facing stringent budgets. As a consequence, we hypothesise that regional decentralisation is harmful to the urban environment in China.

The following sections first describe the structural and spatial pattern of industrial air pollution and then test the theoretical propositions using data on industrial SO2 and soot emissions at the city level during 2004–08 in China.

sec.title: Data on Industrial Air Pollutants in Chinese Cities
sec.p: Economic transition has accelerated the urbanisation and industrialisation process, resulting in increasing concentration of industrial activities and population in Chinese cities, with 45.68 per cent of the population living in urbanised areas in 2008. As a result, industrial air pollution has become a major environmental issue threatening the health of the Chinese people in cities. This phenomenon can be partly explained by the fact that industrial production and daily life in cities directly generate a large amount of air pollution. To investigate the environmental impacts of economic transition, this study selected industrial SO2 and soot emissions as the primary pollution indicators. The existing studies typically apply air pollution data at the provincial level due to the data availability. However, we believe that cities are both the major contributors and victims of industrial air pollution and are the better spatial unit of analysis (Chan and Yao, 2008).

The reason for choosing pollution emissions as indicators is that emissions are caused directly by industrial activities and can capture the direct link between industrial activities and pollution results (He, 2009). Industrial SO2 emissions derive from the combustion of coal and oil, the smelting of non-ferrous metals, petroleum refining and other industrial processes and industrial soot emissions refer to the particulate matter produced as a result of fuel combustion. Data availability dictates that the primary focus of the study is on industrial SO2 and soot emissions. The Urban Statistical Yearbook of China has provided data for the two selected air pollution indicators since 2004 for all prefecture-level cities.

In terms of background context, China has become the largest SO2 emitter in the world and SO2 emissions still constitute one of the most serious air pollution problems in China, causing significant health and ecosystem damage (Cao et al., 2009). Industrial SO2 and soot emissions are also frequently used in similar air pollution studies (Grossman and Krueger, 1991; Antweiler et al., 2001; Cole, 2003, 2004; Poon et al., 2006; He, 2009, 2010) and these indicators are considered to be robust and reliable (He, 2010). Industrial SO2 and soot emissions data are directly collected from factories and estimated by China’s Environmental Protection Agency. The local bureaus calculate emissions from factories by combining factory self-reported data on fuel consumption and industrial processes and periodic boiler stack testing data. The environment protection agency has complete information on their equipment and detailed data on their energy consumption. It is possible to define the emission standard of air pollutants according to the age and technology of the equipment. The approach to calculating mass emissions, while recognised as being less robust than ambient data, is more accurate than ambient data for estimating industrial air pollution. The data obtained by this method can be further verified by data collected through field monitoring (He, 2010).

Meanwhile, it is important to note that industrial SO2 and soot emissions data are from large enterprises, which might understate the total industrial air pollution emissions in China. In fact, independent estimates of SO2 emissions are consistently higher than the official figures from the State Environmental Protection Administration (now Ministry of Environmental Protection) (Ohara et al., 2007; Cao et al., 2009). For instance, Ohara et al. (2007) estimated that China’s SO2 emissions in 2003 were about 70 per cent higher than officially reported. However, as He (2010) argued, given that more than 70 per cent of industrial air pollution comes from the large enterprises, we believe the accuracy problem in the total industrial SO2 and soot emission statistics should be acceptable.

sec.title: Industrial Patterns of Air Pollution in China
sec.p: There have been some structural changes in industrial air pollution in the past decade (Figure 1). The total industrial SO2 emissions decreased from 15.87 million tons in 1998 to 13.46 million tons in 2001 and went up to 20.42 million tons in 2006. This trend has been reversed recently, with 18.39 million tons of SO2 in 2008. Industrial soot emissions have been declining from 11.64 million tons in 1998 to 6.04 million tons in 2008. The Chinese government has designated control zones for SO2 and acid rain, and has developed a battery of policies and regulations to control SO2 emissions since the 1990s (Cao et al., 2009; He, 2005). The policies range from economic incentives such as a nation-wide SO2 emission levy to requirements for SO2 abatement technology in power plants of a particular age and size. The policies have contributed to the decrease of industrial SO2 emissions in the 1990s. As a consequence of sustained economic growth, particularly in heavy industrial sectors such as steel, cement and aluminum, China’s industrial energy consumption, and consequently SO2 emissions, have steadily increased since 2001. In this light, the 11th five-year plan targets the reduction of total SO2 emissions by 10 per cent from the 2005 level by 2010. To meet the target, two major policies are proposed, namely: the proposed shutdown across China of 50GW of inefficient and highly polluting small power plant capacity; and, the installation of flue gas desulphurisation equipment on new and existing coal-fired power plants. Cao et al. (2009) reported that the environmental benefits of the two policies have been substantial, thus shedding some light on the recent declining trend of industrial SO2.

caption.p: Industrial SO2 and soot emissions and their intensities during 1998–2008.

sec.p: To illustrate the recent trends of industrial air pollution in China, we further compute the pollution emission intensity by dividing total industrial pollution emissions by industrial gross output at the 1998 constant price. The 1998 constant price index is calculated using the industrial price indices for manufactured goods, which are available from the China Statistical Yearbook 2009. As shown in Figure 1, both pollutant intensities have been declining during 1998–2008, indicating that industrial production in China has been more effective at reducing air pollution. Industrial SO2 emissions per industrial gross output dropped from 2.38 tons/million yuan to 0.45 tons/million yuan. Industrial soot emissions per industrial gross output decreased from 1.75 tons/million yuan to 0.15 tons/million yuan. Beyond the environmental protection policies already discussed, the technical effects and structural effects have been driving down the intenisty of pollution emissions (He, 2006, 2010).

In terms of the sectoral distribution, industrial air pollution in China is concentrated in several industries (Table 1 and Table 2). Power, natural gas and water production are the most pollution-intensive industries. They consume a large amount of coal, which is a major SO2 and soot emitter. In 1998 and 2008, this sector was responsible for 6.97 million tons and 10.63 million tons of SO2 emissions respectively, accounting for 43.92 per cent and 57.79 per cent of total industrial SO2 emissions in China. Its SO2 emission intensity topped all industries, reaching 17.46 tons/million yuan in 1998 and 4.0 tons/million yuan in 2008. Other prolific SO2 emitters include non-metal mineral products, chemical materials and products, ferrous metal smelting and rolling, non-ferrous metal smelting and rolling, petroleum refining and coking, mining, papermaking and paper products, food, drinks and tobacco manufacturing. These industries are resource-processing and heavy industries, demanding a large amount of energy inputs and emitting much SO2.

caption.p: Industrial SO2 emissions by sector (unit: tons, tons/million yuan)

tr.td: Power, natural gas and water production

sec.p: Overall, during 1998–2008, all industries have been much less pollution intensive. Pollution-intensive industries particularly saw a dramatic decrease in pollution emission intensity. Petroleum refining and coking, ferrous metal smelting and rolling processing industry, plastic products, papermaking and paper products experienced a significant growth of SO2 emissions. The annual growth rate of SO2 emissions is 8.38 per cent for petroleum refining and coking, and 7.36 per cent for ferrous metal smelting and processing. Fortunately, many industries have successfully cut their SO2 emissions. Machinery, electrical equipment and electronics, printing and copying, rubber plastics, fabricated metal products and non-metal mineral products saw the fastest decline in SO2 emissions, with an annual rate of decrease greater than 3 per cent. Furthermore, most pollution-intensive industries experienced more reduction in SO2 emission intensity. For instance, non-metal mineral products decreased their SO2 emission intensity from 7.11 tons/million yuan to 0.87 tons/million yuan, and non-ferrous metal smelting and processing from 4.30 tons/million yuan to 0.51 tons/million yuan. For less pollution-intensive industries, it is also true that more pollution-intensive industries experienced more reduction in SO2 emission intensity. Production in rubber products, textiles, food and drink manufacturing, medical and pharmaceutical industries has significantly been cleaner in the past decade. The stricter requirements for SO2-abatement technology in pollution-intensive production and power generation would partially have contributed to the decrease in industrial SO2 emissions intensity (Cao et al., 2009).

caption.p: Industrial soot emissions by sector (unit: tons, tons/million yuan)

tr.td: Power, natural gas and water production

sec.p: The structural pattern of industrial soot emissions is similar to that of industrial SO2 emissions. Power, natural gas and water production have dominated industrial soot emissions, accounting for 29.36 per cent in 1998 and 41.79 per cent in 2008, followed by non-metal mineral products (22.92 per cent, 16.30 per cent), mining (8.52 per cent, 3.07 per cent), chemical materials and products (4.44 per cent, 7.77 per cent) and ferrous metal smelting and processing (3.04 per cent, 9.44 per cent). Except for petroleum refining and coking, plastic products and ferrous metal smelting and processing, all industries witnessed a significant drop in industrial soot emissions during 1998–2008. Notably, mining, printing and copying and non-metal mineral products experienced the fastest decrease in industrial soot emissions. As a soot-intensive industry, non-metal mineral products saw the most dramatic reduction in soot emission intensity during 1998–2008, declining from 8.33 tons/million yuan to 0.51 tons/million yuan. The decline largely occurred during the period of 1998–2001. By 2008, all soot-intensive industries had a soot emission intensity lower than 0.55 tons/million yuan. Among the relatively less soot-intensive industries, food, drink and tobacco manufacturing, medical and pharmaceutical industry, textiles and garment making, rubber products and fabricated metal products have significantly reduced their soot emission intensities during 1998-2008. For instance, food, drink and tobacco manufacturing reduced its soot intensity from 0.40 tons/million yuan to 0.07 tons/million yuan, rubber products from 0.37 tons/milion yuan to 0.05 tons/million yuan and the medical and pharmaceutical industry from 0.36 tons/million yuan to 0.05 tons/million yuan. By 2008, all less soot-intensive industries had intensities lower than 0.10 tons/million yuan. Industries still differ significantly in soot-emission intensities.

sec.title: The Spatial Pattern of Industrial Air Pollution Intensity in Chinese Cities
sec.p: This study is particularly interested in the interurban differences in industrial air pollution intensity during 2004–08. Based on the data availability, this study maps industrial SO2 and soot emission intensity in 287 cities, including all prefecture-level cities, sub-provincial cities and the centrally administered cities of Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai and Chongqing. The China Urban Statistical Yearbook started to report data on industrial SO2 and industrial soot emissions for Chinese cities from 2003. However, data are missing for 25 cities in the western provinces including Shannxi, Gansu, Qinghai, Ningxia, Xinjiang and Tibet in 2003. Therefore, we focus on the time-period of 2004–08.

Overall, SO2 emissions are distributed in scattered clusters (Figure 2). Notably, the Yangtze River Delta, the Shandong peninsula, the capital region (Beijing–Tianjin–Tangshan), central-northern China (including Southern Hebei, Henan and Shanxi), the Sichuan Basin and the Pearl River Delta are the hotspots. In 2008, northern China became more polluted and industrial SO2 emissions have been increasingly concentrated in the larger more polluted cities. However, during 2004–08, many cities, especially the most polluted cities, significantly reduced industrial SO2 emission intensity. The coastal cities have been the most effective at reducing pollution, while the inland cities still face serious industrial air pollution challenges. The coastal cities have been involved in the process of economic globalisation, highly depending on foreign investment and international markets. Meanwhile, foreign investment and exports were helping to improve environmental standards in the coastal cities. Moreover, the coastal region may face increasingly severe punishments for pollution violations than inland China (van Rooij and Lo, 2010). Under the fiscal decentralisation, the central region has a strong incentive to develop industries, which are highly taxable and profitable but pollution-intensive, resulting in the high pollution emission intensity.

caption.p: Spatial distribution of industrial SO2 emission intensity in Chinese cities in 2004 (left) and 2008 (right).

sec.p: The largest concentration of industrial soot emissions is central-northern China, covering cities in Tianjin, Shanxi, Henan and Hebei provinces. Industrial soot is widely distributed in north-east China. Harbin, Jilin, Tieling, Qiqihar, Jiamusi, Jingzhou and Daqing are heavily polluted by industrial soot. Other dispersed clusters include the Yangtze River Delta, the Guangdong–Guangxi (along Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Nanning, Liuzhou, Guigang and Yulin), the east Sichuan basin, the Wuhan city-region in Hubei and the Chang–Zhu–Tan city-region in Hunan province. During 2004–08, most cities in central China significantly reduced industrial soot emission intensity (Figure 3). Industrial production in north-east China, however, remained largely soot-intensive, especially in cities with a heavy industrial structure, such as Jiamusi, Yichun, Jixi, Fuxin, Mudanjiang, Baishan, Qitaihe, Heihe, Shuangyashan, Hegan, Baicheng and Qiqihar. In addition, Guangxi, Shanxi, north-west Shan-Gan-Ning and the east Sichuan basin also remain soot intensive relative to other cities. In comparison, the coastal cities are much cleaner with the Yangtze River Delta and the Pearl River Delta more effective in limiting the soot emissions in their industrial production.

caption.p: Spatial distribution of industrial soot intensity in Chinese cities in 2004 (left) and 2008 (right).

sec.p: Figures 2 and 3 clearly indicate that industrial air pollution is not evenly distributed in China, with some cities more intensively polluted than others. Existing studies have stressed the scale effect, technique effect and structural effect in industrial air pollution (He, 2006, 2010). This study will highlight the importance of institutional factors associated with the triple process of economic transition in determining industrial pollution emission intensity.

sec.title: Variables and Models
sec.p: To understand the remarkable interurban differences in industrial air pollution intensity, this study will conduct a systematic investigation of determinants of industrial air pollution intensity applying a panel data regression model during 2004–08. The particular focus is on the effects of economic transition and hence the explanatory variables include proxies for marketisation, globalisation and fiscal decentralisation controlling for industrial composition and the EKC effect. The model is as follows

That is, the pollution emission intensity (TSO2 or TSOOT) in city i in year t is a function of theoretically discussed variables, i and t denote city and time, λit is the unobservable time effect, νit is the remainder stochastic disturbance term.

Note that λt is city-invariant and accounts for any time-specific effect that is not included in the regression. All variables are logarithmically transformed. The inclusion of per capita GDP and its square is to test the existence of EKC at the city level. The use of per capita GDP and squared per capita GDP to capture scale and technique effects is consistent with the EKC literature, within which the inverted U-shaped relationship between per capita GDP and pollution is explained largely in terms of the dominance of scale effects at low levels of income and the dominance of technique effects at high income levels (Cole et al., 1997).

The particular interest of this study is the environmental effects of economic transition. As discussed, marketisation has played a significant role in changing industrial air pollution intensity in Chinese cities. We examine the percentages of different types of enterprise in industrial gross output to test the environmental impacts of marketisation, including SOEs (SOES), collectively owned enterprises (COES), limited liability corporations (LIMD), shareholding enterprises (SHOLD) and privately owned enterprises (PRIV). As theoretically discussed, SOEs would be harmful to urban environment and the coefficient on SOES would be positive. The coefficients on other proxies are also expected to be positive. To investigate the environmental impacts of economic globalisation in Chinese cities, we introduce three variables to quantify trade and investment liberalisation. These are the percentage of industrial output by foreign-invested enterprises (FDI) in industrial gross output, the percentage of exports in GDP (EXP) and the percentage of imports in GDP (IMP). If the pollution haven hypothesis holds true, the coefficients on FDI and EXP would be positive, while IMP would have negative coefficients. Fiscal decentralisation is likely to be harmful to the local environment. This study also includes the percentage of local expenditure in local revenue (FDEC) and the percentage of value-added tax in local revenue (VTAX) to test the impacts of fiscal decentralisation. Both coefficients are likely to be positive.

Finally, this study controls the industrial composition of Chinese cities by including the percentages of industrial gross output of nine pollution-intensive industries (INDU) in the models. They comprise mining industries (INDU1), papermaking and paper products (INDU2), petroleum refining and coking (INDU3), chemical materials and products (INDU4), chemical fibre (INDU5), non-metal mineral products (INDU6), ferrous metal smelting and pressing (INDU7), non-ferrous metal smelting and pressing (INDU8) and power, natural gas and water production (INDU9). All variables are summarised in Table 3.

sec.title: Empirical Results
sec.p: Assuming that industrial air pollution emission intensity declined continuously during 2004–08, it is reasonable to apply the time fixed effect model to estimate the coefficients of explanatory variables. The panel data regression results for both industrial SO2 and soot emission intensities are presented in Table 4. The Breusch–Pagan tests indicate the existence of heteroscedasticity and all estimates are corrected for heteroscedasticity. We also separately estimate the environmental impacts of marketisation, globalisation and decentralisation controlling for the EKC effect and industrial composition. The full model includes all explanatory and controlling variables. Overall, statistical results provide strong evidence to support the EKC effect in Chinese cities. Results show that there is a statistically significant inverted U-shaped relationship between lnPGDP and lnTSO2 (or lnTSOOT). In particular, as cities become industrialised, their economies become increasingly pollution-intensive. This is evident in the fact that pollution emission density is lower in underdeveloped cities. When per capita GDP reaches a certain level, pollution emission intensity gradually declines. The significant EKC effect suggests that economic development and economic restructuring would improve the urban environment quality in China.

fn.p: Notes: * p < 0.10; ** p < 0.05; *** p < 0.01. Results are corrected for heteroscedasticity.

sec.p: There is some evidence to show that economic liberalisation has degraded urban environment quality in China. In the SO2 models, the coefficients on lnLIMD and lnSHOLD are positive while both lnPRIV and lnCOES have negative coefficients. However, only lnLIMD has a significant coefficient, indicating that limited liability corporations have been associated with higher industrial SO2 intensity in Chinese cities. In the industrial soot models, coefficients on lnLIMD, lnSHOLD and lnPRIV are positively significant while the coefficient on lnCOES is positive but not statistically significant. These refer to the main types of non-SOEs, with several profit-oriented shareholders. Limited liability corporations, shareholding companies and privately owned enterprises occur to drive up industrial soot emission intensity in Chinese cities. Faced with weaker environmental regulations, the non-SOEs lack incentives to spend to reduce pollution emissions (Eiser et al., 1996). It is also difficult to enforce environmental policies for non-SOEs (Jahiel, 1997). Marketisation appears to have been causing China’s urban air quality to deteriorate.

In both the industrial SO2 and soot emission models, the coefficients on lnSOES are positive and highly significant, implying that SOEs have been associated with China’s environmental degradation. This is consistent with Wang and Wheeler (2000), who found that SOEs are more likely to pollute than privately owned enterprises. SOEs do have stronger bargaining power with local governments regarding environmental regulations and are able to elicit a lower pollution payment or punishment and have less incentive to reduce their pollution (Wang et al., 2001). Moreover, local governments have strong incentives to protect SOEs since there are positive economic benefits to be had from them. For instance, local government officials can arrange employment for their relatives, friends and political supporters in the SOEs and local governments can also divert money from SOEs to public works at best and personal use at worst (Bai et al., 2004). Local protectionism would discourage local governmental agencies to enforce strict environmental regulations.

There is no statistical support for the pollution haven hypothesis. Both coefficients on lnFDI and lnEXP are negative and significant in the model 2 specification in both the industrial SO2 and soot models. Foreign enterprises and exports in Chinese cities are associated with lower levels of industrial air pollution intensities, implying that cities relying on international investments and international markets are less pollution-intensive. The results confirm the argument by Wang and Jin (2002), who found that foreign-owned enterprises have better environmental performance based on individual survey data. The pollution haven hypothesis predicts that the participation in economic globalisation would hurt China’s environment since multinational corporations would seek a pollution haven in China. However, the impact of trade and investment liberalisation on the environment depends on whether or not a country has comparative advantages in pollution-intensive production (Cole, 2003). China’s labour abundance is the comparative advantage and has encouraged the rapid development of labour-intensive industries, attracting foreign investments and promoting exports. labour-intensive industries are less likely to be heavy polluters compared with some capital-intensive industries. In the soot models, lnIMP has a negative and insignificant coefficient but it has a positive and significant coefficient in the SO2 models. China has largely imported natural resources, crude oil and advanced equipment from abroad. More imports possibly reduce industrial soot emissions since more advanced technologies are embedded in the imported equipment and machinery. Imports of natural resources and crude oil largely go to cities specialising in heavy industries or resource-processing economies generating more industrial SO2 emissions.

As expected, fiscal decentralisation has been positively associated with China’s environmental degradation. Both lnFDEC and lnVTAX have positive coefficients in the model 3 and model 4 specifications, indicating that the difficulty of local budgets and the dependence of local revenues on industrial development are positively associated with industrial air pollution intensity. Fiscal decentralisation requires the localities to self-finance their budgets and their own development (Zhao and Zhang, 1999). Fiscal decentralisation and designated local tax structures create strong pressure and incentives to develop industries and to enhance local revenues. Fiscal decentralisation has triggered the ‘race to the bottom’ competition to lower environmental regulations and standards to attract highly taxable and value-added industries, which are typically pollution-intensive (Taguchi and Murofushi, 2010). Cities suffering from restrictive budgets are also more lax with the enforcement of environmental regulations. Regional decentralisation has discouraged local governmental agencies to implement strict environmental regulations for non-SOEs, which themselves lack the incentives to internalise environmental costs. SOEs enjoy more bargaining power in cities faced with restrictive budgets and are more likely to avoid environmental costs. The interplay of marketisation and decentralisation has made China’s environmental protection extremely difficult.

In summary, the triple processes of economic transition have different environmental impacts. Marketisation and decentralisation have contributed to environmental degradation, while economic globalisation is likely to improve China’s urban environment quality. There are, however, significant and remarkable regional differences in China’s economic transition. Chinese regions differ in economic development, location, industrial structure, technology, institutional environment and government policies. To interrogate further the robustness of the estimations, we divide Chinese cities into three groups: cities located in the coastal, central and western provinces.1 Both industrial SO2 and soot models are estimated for the three sub-samples.

The statistical results are reported in Tables 5–7. All models are highly significant. The models perform best in the coastal cities and poorest in the western cities. Panel data regressions reveal some regional differences in the impacts of economic transition on industrial air pollution intensity. There is a U-shaped rather than inverted U-shaped relationship between lnPGDP and lnTSO2 and lnTSOOT in the coastal cities. The EKC effects are likely to occur in the inland cities, implying that it is possible to improve the urban environment quality in inland cities by facilitating economic growth. The inverted EKC effect is possibly related to the heavy industrialisation recently occurring in the coastal region. Since the late 1990s, a number of developed coastal provinces have started to upgrade their industrial structures by developing heavy industries such as chemical materials and products, steel making and machinery and equipment. The international relocation of heavy industries to China and strong domestic demand expectations, together with the local governments’ desire for GDP have initiated the recent heavy industrialisation in China.

sec.p: Regarding the environmental impacts of the triple process of economic transition, the coastal and central regions provide rather consistent results with the full sample estimates, while the western region barely sees significant evidence. In the coastal cities, lnPRIV has an insignificant coefficient in the industrial SO2 models, but proxies for other non-SOEs have significant and positive coefficients in both the SO2 and soot models, indicating that developing non-SOEs such as limited liability corporations, shareholding companies and collectively-owned enterprises may be harmful to urban environment in the coastal cities. In the central cities models, coefficients on lnLMID, lnSHOLD and lnPRIV are positive and the development of limited liability corporations and privately owned enterprises has significantly reduced pollution emission intensity in the central cities. In the western cities models, only lnLIMD has a significant positive coefficient. Other proxies have negative but insignificant coefficients. As a consequence, there is solid evidence to argue that economic liberalisation has degraded the urban environment in the coastal and central cities.

Interestingly, lnCOES has negatively significant coefficients in the central cities models, implying that collectively owned enterprises have been good for the urban environment. In the less developed central region, the state still controls the heavy and high value-added pollution-intensive industries, while collectively owned enterprises are largely in light industries and thereby more pollution effective. As expected, lnSOES has positive and significant coefficients in the coastal and central cities models, but insignificant negative coefficients in the western cities models. SOEs hurt the urban environment in the coastal and central regions controlling for industrial composition. In the coastal and central cities, SOEs are largely in the heavy industries such as chemical materials and chemical products, and ferrous metal mineral smelting and processing, equipment and machinery. They are major value-added taxpayers and GDP contributors and have stronger bargain power. SOEs are likely to pollute more.

Significant regional differences regarding the environmental impacts of economic globalisation are also evident. In the coastal and western cities models, lnFDI is barely significant but has negative and significant coefficients in the central cities models. Foreign investments in central cities are either in labour-intensive light industries or in high-tech industries such as electronics, lowering air pollution emissions. Exports have clearly improved the air quality in the coastal cities, as illustrated by the significant negative coefficients on lnEXP in the coastal models. However, in the central cities models, the coefficients on lnEXP are positive and significant in the soot model specification. Consistent with its comparative advantages, the central region has exported resource-intensive products, which are more pollution-intensive. In addition, imports have no environmental impacts in the coastal region. Imports are likely to improve urban air quality in the central region, but have negative impacts on the environment in the west. The estimates for the three regions provide further evidence to argue that the pollution haven hypothesis does not hold in China.

Fiscal decentralisation has had significant impacts on the urban environment in the central cities. Both lnFDEC and lnVTAX are highly significant in the central cities models, indicating that cities suffering from restrictive budgets and depending on industrial value-added tax for revenues endure serious air pollution. Incentives in economic growth and pressure in local revenues would induce the development of pollution-intensive industries in the central cities. In the past couple of years, the central region has gained rather favourable policy support from the central government and has competed to attract relocated industries from the coastal cities. The relocated industries are partially forced to move due to environmental pollution. In addition, in the coastal cities models, lnFDEC is positive and significant only in the soot model specifications, while lnVTAX is positive and significant in the SO2 model specifications. Therefore, fiscal decentralisation may have contributed to the environmental degradation in the coastal cities. The central government transfers a significant amount of money to the western provinces, thereby downplaying the negative environmental impacts of regional decentralisation in the western cities. Overall, economic transition has significant environmental consequences, particularly in coastal and central China.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: Economic transition in the past three decades has liberalised the Chinese economy, resulting in eye-catching economic growth. It has, however, imposed a serious challenge for environment protection in China. This study has investigated the environmental impacts of marketisation, globalisation and decentralisation using data on industrial SO2 and soot emissions at the prefecture-city level during 2004–08.

China’s industrial production has experienced declining air pollution intensity during the past decade. Industrial air pollution has been concentrated in several pollution-intensive industries. Furthermore, in terms of geographical trends, industrial air pollution is clustered in some Chinese cities. The Yangtze River Delta, the Shandong peninsula, the capital region, central-northern China, north-eastern China, the Sichuan basin and the Pearl River Delta are the hotspots.

Statistical results confirm that the triple process of marketisation, globalisation and decentralisation has multifarious environment effects in Chinese cities. Marketisation and decentralisation have been partially responsible for poorer urban air quality, while economic globalisation is likely to improve China’s urban environment. There is no evidence to support the pollution haven hypothesis. Fiscal decentralisation seems to have induced a ‘race to the bottom’ competition and lower environmental regulations to attract taxable and high value-added pollution-intensive industries. However, the environmental impacts of economic transition occur only in the coastal and central regions, but not in the western region. As a landlocked remote area, China’s west has been lagging far behind in liberalising and globalising its economy and has received a sizeable monetary transfer from the central government to relieve its budget difficulty, undermining the environmental influence of economic transition.

As outlined in the paper, China’s remarkable economic growth is accompanied by serious environmental degradation. Existing studies found the importance of the scale effect, technique effect and structural effect in determining industrial air pollution. This study has confirmed the significance of institutional effects. Marketisation has returned decision-making power to enterprises, while regional decentralisation shifts power from the central government to the locales. Power and fiscal decentralisation have induced local governments to implement lax environmental regulations, reducing the incentives of industrial enterprises to internalise environmental costs. Evidence from the paper suggests that it is imperative to grant local governments incentives to pursue environmentally friendlyeconomic development models. The improvement of China’s urban environment depends on the effort of local governments. However, this has to be supported by a set of reforms, including reforming the structure of local revenues and changing performance evaluation system for local governments. It is also critical to strengthen the authority and independence of local environment protection agencies.
